messages.content: 9-1-1, what's your emergency?
Okay, and when you say he's down, what do you mean?
She says he's cold and he's not breathing.
She says she's been trying to give him CPR.
Okay. Is there any way you can get a phone, a cell phone, or something over there to him?
Well, I'll tell you what, I'm giving it to her right here. Here she is, right here.
Okay. Hello, ma'am.
Yes, ma'am.
Okay. Can you get in there with him?
I've been there trying to do mouth-to-mouth, but he's cold and stiff, really cold and stiff.
Okay.
And I've been gone all day hunting for him because he's got a lot of mental problems, and he likes to go down to Durham and Raleigh.
And he was stopped by the Apex Police about a year ago because it was like 4 in the morning, and he was out there.
Okay.
He was going to go to the gang areas and get killed because he doesn't want to die of his lymphoma.
Okay. Do you have a cell phone at all?
Yeah, but it died. It died.
What's your name?
Jolene Hardy.
Jolene Harvey?
Hardy. H-A-R-D-Y.
Okay. Alright. I'm just going to ask you some questions. How old is he?
He's 60 years old.
Okay.
I'm going to sit down before I fall down.
Okay. I have them on the way to you. I'm just going to talk to you while they're on the way.
I'm at my neighbor's house right now because I tried all that time to resuscitate him and he's so cold and I couldn't stand it anymore.
I came over here because it finally dawned on me I wasn't getting anywhere with it and he just got colder.
I've been hunting for him all last night and all day. I haven't had any sleep.
He's been doing these things for six years since he got sick.
Okay, last you were over there with him, was he awake?
No, he was as cold as a bone.
Was he breathing?
No, he's stiff and cold as a bone. I blew in his mouth and nothing happened. His chest didn't rise or anything because he's already cold.
Okay. Do you think he's beyond any help?
Oh, God, yes.
I've never seen a dead person outside of a coffin, and I had to put my mouth on his. It was so cold and his teeth are all knocked out.
His teeth are knocked out?

Yes, because he hangs out sometimes he goes down to Raleigh and Durham and he walks. About a year ago, the Apex Police saw him at 4 in the morning heading toward Raleigh. They stopped and talked to him.
He said, is there a law against me walking down the street at 4 in the morning? They said, well, no. He said, well, I'm not a window peeper or nothing. Can't I be on my way? And they said, yes.
Jolene, when's the last time you saw him?
I saw him early yesterday morning. And then he took off somewhere that evening.
When's the last time you were home?
I've been out all night and all day looking for him.
Okay.
I got home about 3:30 this afternoon.
So before 3:30 this afternoon, when was the last time you were physically home?
I was home once early morning, and he wasn't there then. But when I came back now, he is.
Okay, and you've been doing CPR?
Yes, I have.
I got a heart condition and high blood pressure and cholesterol, and I got sugar diabetes a little bit. And I couldn't breathe deep enough, but I mean, he was already sitting cold.
He had to come home sometime in the morning time, not early morning, but later morning. Because I just went in there about 3:30.
Okay, is that the ambulance I hear pulling up?
Yes, I hear it.
Okay, go ahead and talk to them.
Alright.
Thank you. Bye-bye.
